name: 1-Bromo-4-methylbenzene
Reason: The target compound, 1-Bromo-4-methylbenzene, has a benzene ring as its basic unit which has a melting point of 5.5°C. Adding a methyl group to a benzene ring typically has a mild effect on the melting point, and it can be estimated to raise the melting point due to the slight increase in molecular weight and steric hindrance, approximated at +3°C. Adding a bromine atom significantly increases the molecular weight and introduces stronger intermolecular forces through increased polarizability, which translates to a larger increase in the melting point. For bromine, the effect can be estimated at +18°C. Therefore, the combined effects of the methyl and bromine groups are predicted to increase the melting point of benzene.
Test (Predicted reason):
The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. The methyl group, being a small alkyl group, will have a smaller effect on the melting point compared to larger substituents.
